title: What is the tangent to the circle whose equation is x^2+y^2=4? - Quora

response.answer_text: I like calculus questions I can do with middle school math. I know two ways to do this one. Method 1: Let [math](a,b)[/math] be the point on the circle where we want the tangent. The radius is on the line through [math](a,b)[/math] and [math](0,0),[/math] that line being [math]ay=bx.[/math] Our radius is on [math] bx-ay=0,[/math] so our tangent is one of the family of perpendiculars, [math] ax+by=\textrm{constant}.[/math] (I won’t justify the mechanical procedure writing the perpendiculars by losing the constant, swapping coefficients on [math]x[/math] and [math]y,[/math] and flipping one of their signs, but you should if it’s news to you.) [math](a,b)[/math] is on the tangent line so we plug it in to get the constant. We see our line must be [math] ax+by=a^2+b^2.[/math] We actually could stop here and be perfectly correct. We never explicitly used the radius. There’s one more simplification. Since [math](a,b)[/math] is on the circle [math] a^2+ b^2=4[/math]. So the tangent line at [math](a,b)[/math] is [math]ax+by=4.[/math] Method 2: [math]x^2+y^2=4[/math] Let [math](a,b)[/math] be a point on the circle as before. We’re interested in what happens near [math](a,b)[/math] so into our circle equation we substitute [math]x=a+(x-a)[/math] and [math]y=b+(y-b)[/math]. [math](a+(x-a))^2 + (b+(y-b))^2 = 4[/math] [math]a^2 + 2 a(x-a) + (x-a)^2 + b^2 + 2b(y-b) + (y-b)^2 = 4 [/math] When we’re near [math](a,b)[/math], that means [math]x-a[/math] and [math]y-b[/math] are small, and [math](x-a)^2[/math] and [math](y-b)^2[/math] are smaller still. Let’s sort by increasing degree. [math]a^2 + b^2  + 2 a(x-a)  + 2b(y-b) + (x-a)^2 + (y-b)^2 = 4[/math] If we say [math](x-a)^2[/math] and [math](y-b)^2[/math] are so small that they disappear, we’re left with the tangent line: [math]a^2 + b^2 + 2 a(x-a) + 2b(y-b)  = 4[/math] We already know [math]a^2+b^2=4.[/math] [math] 2 a(x-a) + 2b(y-b) = 0[/math] [math]ax + by =a^2 + b^2[/math] [math]ax + by = 4[/math] Method 3: Something to do with [math]\dfrac{dy}{dx},[/math] I forget. Oh yeah. [math]x^2 + y^2 = 4[/math] Taking derivatives with respect to [math]x,[/math] [math]2 x + 2y \dfrac{dy}{dx} = 0[/math] [math]\dfrac{dy}{dx} = - \dfrac x y[/math] That’s the slope of the tangent at ([math]x,y).[/math] We need [math]x[/math] and [math]y[/math] as variables to write the line, so we’ll investigate the tangent at our point on the circle [math](a,b).[/math] There the slope of the tangent will be [math]-\dfrac a b[/math] and [math](a,b)[/math] is on the line, so the tangent line is [math]\dfrac{y - b}{x-a} = -\dfrac a b[/math] [math]y - b = - \dfrac a b (x-a)[/math] [math]by - b^2 = -ax + a^2[/math] [math]ax + by = a^2 + b^2 = 4[/math] The calculus solution is not quite as good, because technically this derivation doesn’t work when [math]b=0.[/math]
